title: 105_s2433
content: TITLE X--FINANCIAL INFORMATION PRIVACY PROTECTION: The Consumer Credit Protection Act is amended to include provisions for protecting financial information privacy. The Financial Information Privacy Act includes sections on short title, definitions, privacy protection for customer information, administrative enforcement, civil liability, criminal penalty, relation to State laws, and agency guidance. The Act defines terms like 'customer' and 'customer information of a financial institution'. The Financial Information Privacy Act defines terms like 'customer information of a financial institution' as any information maintained by a financial institution derived from the relationship with a customer, and 'financial institution' as any institution providing financial services to customers with accounts or relationships. The Financial Information Privacy Act defines 'financial institution' as any entity providing financial services to customers with accounts or relationships, including depository institutions, loan companies, credit card issuers, and consumer reporting agencies. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System may further define this term through regulations. The Financial Information Privacy Act allows the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System to define 'financial institution' for regulatory purposes. The Act prohibits obtaining customer information through false pretenses. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information through false pretenses, such as making false statements to deceive financial institution officers or customers. This includes providing forged or fraudulent documents to obtain customer information. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information through false pretenses, including providing forged or fraudulent documents with the intent to deceive. It is also a violation to request someone to obtain customer information from a financial institution under false pretenses. This does not apply to law enforcement agencies. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information through false pretenses. Law enforcement agencies are exempt from this provision. Financial institutions can still obtain customer information for security testing or investigating misconduct. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information through false pretenses, with exemptions for law enforcement agencies. Financial institutions can still access customer information for security testing or investigating misconduct. Administrative enforcement is carried out by the Federal Trade Commission. Enforcement of compliance with this title is done by the Federal Trade Commission, with the same power as under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. Compliance can also be enforced by other agencies in certain cases, such as the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency for national banks. The Act applies to member banks of the Federal Reserve System, branches and agencies of foreign banks, commercial lending companies owned by foreign banks, and organizations operating under specific sections of the Federal Reserve Act. It also applies to banks insured by the FDIC and insured State branches of foreign banks. It applies to member banks of the Federal Reserve System, branches and agencies of foreign banks, commercial lending companies owned by foreign banks, and organizations operating under specific sections of the Federal Reserve Act. Additionally, it applies to banks insured by the FDIC, insured State branches of foreign banks, savings associations with insured deposits, and Federal credit unions. Violations of this Act are treated as violations of other laws by relevant regulatory agencies. Agencies referred to in the Act have the authority to enforce compliance with the Act and may exercise any other authority conferred on them by law. States also have the authority to take action against violations of the Act. If a State enforcement officer suspects a violation of the Financial Information Privacy Act, the State can take legal action in federal court, seek damages on behalf of residents, and recover costs and attorney fees. Federal regulators must be given prior notice before any action is taken by the State. The State must provide prior notice to federal regulators before taking legal action in federal court for suspected violations of the Financial Information Privacy Act. The Federal Trade Commission and relevant agencies have the right to intervene in such actions. The Federal Trade Commission and relevant agencies have the right to intervene in legal actions related to suspected violations of the Financial Information Privacy Act. They can be heard on all matters, remove the action to the appropriate court, and file petitions for appeal. No provision shall prevent state law enforcement officers from exercising their powers for bringing such actions. The Federal Trade Commission and relevant agencies have the authority to intervene in legal actions regarding suspected violations of the Financial Information Privacy Act. State law enforcement officers are not restricted from exercising their powers to bring actions. During a federal civil action for a violation of the Act, no State can initiate a separate action against a defendant named in the federal complaint. Civil liability is addressed in Section 1005. Section 1005 of the Financial Information Privacy Act addresses civil liability for non-compliance with the provisions of the Act. Any person, other than a financial institution, who fails to comply shall be liable to the financial institution or customer for actual damages sustained as a result of the failure. This includes any amount received by the non-compliant person, including nonmonetary consideration. Sec. 1006 of the Financial Information Privacy Act outlines criminal penalties for violating section 1003, including fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years. Enhanced penalties apply for aggravated cases involving violations of other US laws or illegal activities. Sec. 1006 of the Financial Information Privacy Act outlines penalties for violating section 1003, including fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years. Violations in conjunction with other US laws or illegal activities exceeding $100,000 in a 12-month period may result in double fines or up to 10 years imprisonment. Sec. 1007 clarifies that state laws are not superseded unless inconsistent with federal provisions. Sec. 1008 of the Financial Information Privacy Act requires Federal banking agencies to issue advisories to depository institutions to help prevent and detect prohibited activities under section 1003. Before the end of 18 months from enactment, a report must be submitted to Congress by the Comptroller General, in consultation with relevant agencies, on related matters. The Comptroller General, in consultation with relevant agencies, will submit a report to Congress on the effectiveness of remedies in addressing fraudulent attempts to obtain financial information and recommendations for legislative or regulatory actions to protect financial privacy.
